text: we all know what this is it's a 20 pound
note and this is what three hundred and
sixty 1 million pounds looks like in 20
pound notes and if you believe the
headlines that's what we're handing over
to the EU every week or is it well the
short answer is no the UK doesn't hand
over this much money to the EU let me
explain in 1984 Margaret Thatcher
negotiated the rebate an instant
discount taken from the money the UK
pays before it's sent in 2014 the rebate
was worth 85 million pounds a week
leaving 276 million being sent to the EU
but that's not the full story because
the money flows in both directions every
week the UK Treasury gets 88 million
pounds from the EU and it's divided up
into five main areas fifty million
pounds of that is spent on farming and
Fisheries most of it goes direct to
farmers to keep them in business another
11 million pounds goes to rural
development to help them improve and
maintain life in the countryside every
week 20 million pounds is spent on
developing less prosperous parts of the
country is spent on things like
transport infrastructure and helping
businesses to grow 5 million pounds goes
to Social Development tackling things
like poverty and unemployment and the
money goes to education and training and
that last piece 2 million pounds goes to
other EU projects here in the UK we're
talking about things like medical
research or low carbon energy funds so
if we subtract what the UK Treasury gets
back we end up with a weekly
contribution of a hundred and eighty
eight million pounds
but the UK private sector also gets
money from the EU in three main areas in
scientific research in university
funding and in engineering projects add
that up at its 27 million pounds a week
that means when you take away the rebate
the EU money is sent to the Treasury and
the private sector funding 161 million
pounds a week is going to the EU so how
does that stack up well every week the
UK spends 821 million pounds on defense
it spends 1.4 billion pounds on
education on the NHS 2.6 billion pounds
and on top of that it spends 3.6 billion
pounds on pensions so the price of EU
membership 161 million pounds a week is
it worth it well the voters will decide
